Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Intensification of propylene oxide manufacture via solid-catalyst design
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project aims to develop a delaminated zeolite-based catalyst to facilitate more economical and environmentally friendly propylene-oxide (PO) production. PO is a commodity chemical with a $5.6B/year market. The two current pain points for PO producers are (i) that the currently used industrial catalyst lacks long-term stability under the harsh conditions at the tail-end of the PO synthesis reactor, and (ii) as a result of catalyst deficiency, that the process to manufacture PO consumes an extra $140M of raw materials per year, separate from the problem in (i) above. Berkeley Materials Solutions developed a catalyst for the tail-end of the PO synthesis reactor that nearly eliminates both of these problems. The catalyst allows for nearly 100% conversion of all raw material into PO, which leads to $145 M/year of additional revenue for PO producers, corresponding to a revenue increase of 8.6%. This increased revenue comes at no additional cost since it is a drop-in replacement. In addition, there are significant energy efficiency improvements associated with recovering the currently lost raw material in the PO synthesis process, which amounts to a CO2 footprint of ~740 kilo tons of CO2 per year worldwide.

The intellectual merit of this project will be represented by the development of a generalizable crystalline catalyst platform to replace existing amorphous catalysts. Technical hurdles that will be addressed in the proposal are (i) the successful delamination of a layered zeolite precursor using a swelling method and sonication, (ii) establishing a sonication-free scalable delamination method for layered zeolite precursors, and (iii) the insertion of catalytically active heteroatom sites into the delaminates frameworks. If successful, this will enable the economical production of these zeolite catalysts for application in the PO synthesis reactor under flow conditions. The targeted scales even during Phase I activities are large enough to enable testing in collaboration with industrial partners who manufacture propylene oxide at large scales. These test results will be used to optimize the prototype catalyst. The results from Phase I activities will help to uncover other possible opportunities to use delaminated zeolites as highly efficient catalysts for chemical manufacturing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During SBIR Phase I activities, Berkeley Materials Solutions (BMS) developed a crystalline catalyst platform that aims to replace the amorphous catalyst that is currently used in commercial propylene oxide (PO) manufacturing. PO is a commodity chemical that is used to produce foams for upholstery and building insulation, as well as polyols for plastics and antifreeze. Its annual production is about 9 million tons per year, valued at $11 billion / year and its demand is growing at an annual rate of 3-5%. The PO synthesis method that BMS is targeting produces PO by reacting propylene with an organic hydroperoxide, producing PO and an organic alcohol co-product. Over 47% of the worldwide PO produced uses this co-product route. Interviews with PO manufacturers revealed that this process suffers from rapid deactivation of the solid catalyst, because it does not withstand the harsh conditions of the PO synthesis reactor, where corrosive organic hydroperoxides and alcohols are present. Over a period of 4-6 weeks after its deployment, the conventional amorphous catalyst that is used for commercial PO manufacturing deactivates and has to be replaced. Catalyst replacement leads to reactor downtime during which no PO is produced and no profit is generated. In addition, the elevated temperatures required to compensate for catalyst deactivation lead to decreasing catalyst selectivity - a measure of how much PO product is formed for each equivalent organic hydroperoxide consumed - thereby further decreasing product yield and profit valued at $930 million per year, not to mention increasing the CO2 environmental footprint of the process.

During NSF SBIR Phase I activities, BMS validated its catalyst platform technology by developing an optimized crystalline catalyst for 1-octene epoxidation with organic hydroperoxide, leading to a catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability (i.e. lack of deactivation) for epoxidation catalysis that exceed that of the industrial amorphous catalyst, in flow reactor testing. (BMS chose 1-octene as olefin substrate instead of the industrially relevant propylene because time and capital resources for the construction of a high-pressure PO synthesis reactor were inaccessible to BMS during the NSF SBIR Phase I period. 1-octene behaves similar to propylene and is commonly used as a surrogate reactant for propylene, in the development of catalysts for PO manufacture. BMS (as well as PO producers) therefore use 1-octene as an olefin reactant to inform the development of and validate new PO catalyst technology, as a stepping stone before testing it with propylene in a dedicate PO synthesis flow reactor unit.) In particular, when using the organic hydroperoxide used by Shell for PO manufacture, the BMS catalyst showed a higher stability and selectivity in a 200-hour flow reactor experiment. BMS developed new approaches for its catalyst synthesis platform that were more economical and environmentally friendly; both aspects are important for catalyst manufacturers for the large-scale production of the BMS catalyst. The BMS catalyst synthesis platform based on these new approaches produced epoxidation catalysts of high activity, stability, and selectivity that were comparable or better than those of the previous-generation BMS platform. Catalysts resulting from this new BMS catalyst synthesis platform have been successfully validated in flow reactor studies with two organic hydroperoxides that are used for commercial PO production by LyondellBasell and Shell in conjunction with 1-octene as terminal olefin reactant.
